author: By Tom Edgington
title: Council tax: What is it and how much is it rising?
content: Labour would freeze council tax this year if it was in government, the party announced as it launched its campaign for the May local elections.The pledge comes as millions of households in England face a 5% rise <https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-64627967> in April, with bills in the rest of the UK also expected to rise sharply.Council tax is a compulsory charge on properties in England, Scotland and Wales set by local authorities to raise money to spend on providing services in their area.Homes are graded into different "bands", according to how much they were worth at a certain point in time.In England, for example, bands are based on what the value of the property would have been on 1 April 1991.People with more expensive properties are in a higher category.In Scotland, councils have complete freedom to set rates <https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-60509673>. In Wales,local councils set rates, but the government can cap council tax rises that are deemed "excessive" <https://researchbriefings.files.parliament.uk/documents/SN06583/SN06583.pdf>.Northern Ireland, is not covered by the council tax system - it operates a separatedomestic rating system <https://www.nidirect.gov.uk/campaigns/a-guide-to-rates>.Bills are calculated according to property value using what is known as the district rate, set by councils, and the regional rate, usually set by the Northern Ireland Assembly.The government has increased the amount that councils in England are allowed to put up council tax without having to hold a local referendum.Those with social care duties can raise council tax by 5%, while others can put it up by 3%.Most councils are expected to impose the biggest increase they are allowed to without consulting residents.In November 2022, the Treasury said it expected 95% of eligible councils to push ahead with the 5% rise <https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-63673838>.Labour leader Keir Starmer said he would cover the cost of freezing council tax rates if he was in office by increasing thewindfall tax on energy firms <https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-60295177>.In England, if you pay the average Band D council tax <https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/1076602/Council_Tax_Levels_Set_by_Local_Authorities_in_England_2022-23__revised_.pdf> of £1,966 a year and your council tax goes up by 5%, that would mean an extra £98.30 across the year, or £8.19 a month.To find out how much you are currently paying in England or Wales, search for your property on the government website <https://www.tax.service.gov.uk/check-council-tax-band/search>.That site tells you which tax band you are in and which council you pay it to, with a link to its website. There you should be able to find details of your current bill, and how much it will go up in April.In Wales, the average hike is set to be 5.5% <https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-wales-64799857>, with Conwy seeing the highest annual rise of almost 10%. Torfaen and Blaenau Gwent will see some of the lowest increases.In Scotland,you can go to the Scottish Assessors Association website <https://www.saa.gov.uk/> to find your council tax band and a link to your local authority.All 32 local authorities in Scotland have now set their council tax rates for the coming year -with 22 opting for a 3% rise <https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-60509673>.Just two went above 3% - East Renfrewshire (3.5%) and Falkirk (4%).In Northern Ireland, you need to check the valuation of your property <https://valuationservices.finance-ni.gov.uk/Property/Search>. In the absence of a sitting assembly, the Northern Ireland Office said in February thatregional rates will rise by 6% from April. <https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-64746967>The average domestic district rate increase - set individually by Northern Ireland's 15 councils - is 6.67%.Council tax helps fund a number of local services, including:It is the main source of income for most councils. According to the Institute for Government, on averagecouncil tax provides about half of local authorities' funding in England <https://www.instituteforgovernment.org.uk/explainers/local-government-funding-england>.A further 27% of council funding comes from business rates, while the remaining 23% comes from central government grants.In England, an additional charge is levied which goes towards the cost of care homes and other adult social care services.As well as the amount taken by councils - which makes up the majority of a bill - local police and fire authorities also charge council tax to help fund their services.Research from the County Council Network released in March says that - despite the sharp increases -England's largest councils need to make at least £1bn in savings <https://www.countycouncilsnetwork.org.uk/englands-largest-councils-need-to-make-1bn-worth-of-savings-despite-council-tax-rises-as-local-authorities-grapple-with-unprecedented-financial-pressures/> due to "unprecedented" financial pressures.As a rule of thumb, anyone who is over 18 and owns or rents a home has to pay council tax, but there are exemptions and discounts based on individual circumstances.Someone living alone, for example, is entitled to a 25% discount <https://www.gov.uk/council-tax/who-has-to-pay#:~:text=You%20need%20to%20apply%20for,you%20live%20on%20your%20own>.A property occupied solely by students is exempt, and you won't get a bill if you're living in halls of residence or a care home.If you work away from home and your property is empty, you can get a 50% discount.Crucially the occupant of the property is liable for the bill, so tenants have to pay, unless their rent agreement explicitly includes bills.
